questions.question: A patient with a persistent cough and fever undergoes diagnostic testing, revealing acid-fast bacilli in a sputum sample stained with Ziehl-Neelsen stain. Which of the following characteristics of the bacteria contributes to its ability to retain the stain despite acid-alcohol decolourisation?

options.B: Mycolic acids in the cell wall

questions.explanation: found in the cell wall of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. They contribute to the hydrophobic nature of the cell wall, which retains stains like Ziehl-Neelsen despite acid-alcohol decolourisation. Mode of transmission of TB Spread via r espiratory droplets from coughs or sneezes of infected individuals. Other modes are: Inoculation Ingestion Antigenic Structure Cell wall antigens: Peptidoglycan layer Arabinogalactan layer Mycolic acid layer: Principal constituent and is responsible for the acid fastness and also reduces the entry of most antibiotics Outermost lipid layer Protein layer Lipoarabinomannan layer in the plasma membrane, which is used as a target antigen for TB diagnosis Cytoplasmic antigens: Antigen 5 Antigen 60 Cell wall of M. Tuberculosis tuberculosis cell wall structure" data-author="Kleinnijenhuis, J., Oosting, M., B. Joosten, L. A., Netea, M. G., & Crevel, R. V." data-hash="10328" data-license="CC BY 3.0" data-source="https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1155/2011/405310" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/OHAyvy6IviOHftufgHW81744636909.png" /> Lipopolysaccharide (LPS) in the cell wall (Option A): LPS is typically found in gram-negative bacteria and is not a component of the cell wall of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. This option is incorrect. Biofilm formation (Option C): Mycobacterium tuberculosis can form biofilms in certain conditions, but this characteristic does not directly contribute to its ability to retain acid-fast staining. This option is incorrect. Capsular polysaccharides (Option D): Mycobacterium tuberculosis does not produce a capsule that would affect acid-fast staining. This option is incorrect. Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, Apurba S Sastry, 3rd Edition- Page 623, 624

questions.question: A 30-year-old patient presents with a cough for 3 weeks, weight loss, fever, and blood in sputum. Chest X-ray reveals a small granuloma in the mid-lung region along with enlarged hilar lymph nodes. Which of the following terms best describes these findings in the context of primary pulmonary tuberculosis?
questions.explanation: the lung parenchyma known as a Ghon focus. The combination of this granuloma and the adjacent hilar lymph node involved without any calcification is referred to as a Ghon /primary complex Clinical manifestations of Mycobacterium tuberculosis: Pulmonary tuberculosis is most common in India. Primary tuberculosis Post-primary or secondary tuberculosis Miliary tuberculosis (option D ruled out) Initial infection by the bacteria in the host. Ghon’s focus (option C ruled out): the subpleural focus of tuberculous pneumonia representing the initial site of infection and the primary response of the host. Common location: lower lobe or the lower part of the upper lobe primary complex (option B): Ghon’s focus together with the enlarged hilar lymph node. Ranke complex (option A ruled out): Healed calcified nodules from primary infection. Post-primary progression or reactivation of latent infection, or exogenous reinfection. Common location: upper lobes of the lungs. Lesions undergo necrosis and destruction of tissues leading to cavitation. Lymph node involvement is uncommon. It is caused in immunocompromised individuals where the bacteria in primary or secondary infection can spread causing dissemination to other organs. Genitourinary tract Lymph nodes (cervical lymphadenitis) Central nervous system (meningitis) Bone and joint (arthritis and osteomyelitis) Peritoneum Gastrointestinal system Pericardium Larynx Pleural lining (pleuritis) Reference: Textbook of Microbiology, Ananthanarayan & Paniker, 10th Edition, Page 356 Bailey & Scott's Diagnostic Microbiology, 15th Edition, Page 533. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6857397/#:~:text =The%20majority%20of%20cases%20were,was%20present%20only%20among%20females.

questions.question: Which of the following diagnostic tests on sputum is most appropriate as an initial test for a case of suspected tuberculosis?
questions.explanation: expensive than NAAT and useful in rapid detection and determining infectiousness as the incidence of false-positive smears is very low with the maintenance of good quality control. Diagnostic test Key concepts Microscopy (useful in rapid detection and determining infectiousness) Ziehl-Neelsen technique (ZN) (hot stain procedure) (Option D) Smears are dried, heat-fixed and stained Carbol fuschin, sulphuric acid, methylene blue Kinyoun acid-fast stain (cold stain procedure) No heating. Fluorochrome Stain Smears are stained with auramine phenol or auramine rhodamine fluorescent dyes Examined under ultraviolet illumination Culture Solid media Löwenstein-Jensen media Cultures are examined weekly for growth Negative cultures (no growth) are reported, and the cultures are discarded only after 8 weeks of incubation Liquid media Middlebrook 7H9 broth, BACTEC 12B medium, MGIT, BacT Alert Reduces the isolation turnaround time down to about ten days Animal inoculation Inoculated intramuscularly Immunodiagnosis Mantoux test (Option C ruled out) Demonstration of hypersensitivity to tuberculoprotein. 0.1 ml of PPD containing 5 TU (tuberculosis unit) is injected intradermally, induration of 10mm or more is positive. Interferon-gamma release assay (IGRAs) (Option A ruled out) Mycobacterium TB antigen CFP10 is used in the test, and it reacts with the patient's T cells to release γ interferons. Molecular Tests Genetic Sequencing and Nucleic Acid Amplification (Option B ruled out) PCR amplification of mycobacterial DNA with genus-specific primers. Xpert MTB/RIF (also detects the mutations associated with rifampin resistance) DNA Microarrays Quick analysis of many DNA sequences using just one hybridization step. Reference: Bailey & Scott's Diagnostic Microbiology, 15th Edition, Page 545, 546-551.

questions.explanation: where the mycobacterial growth uses oxygen, leading to fluorescence. questions.question: A microbiology laboratory wants to implement an automated system for the detection of mycobacteria in clinical specimens. Which of the following is the primary detection method used by the BacT/ALERT system to identify bacterial growth? I production using colorimetric sensors

options.C: Detection of pressure changes due to gas production

questions.explanation: I production using colorimetric sensors I production using colorimetric sensors Explanation: The BacT/ALERT system uses colorimetric sensors to detect CO I production from metabolizing bacteria. As bacteria grow and produce CO I , the system senses a colour change, indicating bacterial presence and growth. Newer automated methods Bactec MGIT 960 MGIT: Mycobacterial Growth Indicator Tube Middlebrook 7h9 Broth is used Principle: In the presence of oxygen, fluorescence is quenched Bacteria use oxygen while growing causing fluorescence (Options A & D ruled out) It can detect both Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex and nontuberculous mycobacteria. Incubation temperature: 37 °C Bac T/alert Colorimetric detection of CO2 produced by growing bacteria. (Option B) Versatrek Detects pressure changes in media due to gas production. (Option C ruled out) Reference: Bailey & Scott's Diagnostic Microbiology, 14th Edition, Page 478-479,193-194 Murray's Medical Microbiology, 9th Edition, Page 235-236 Textbook of Microbiology, Ananthanarayan & Paniker, 10th Edition, Page 351-352

questions.question: A 45-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with a persistent cough with blood in sputum, fever, and weight loss. The chest X-ray shows infiltrates in the upper lobes. The clinician wants a rapid and reliable test for diagnosing. Which of the following statements about the GeneXpert MTB/RIF assay is correct?

options.A: It can detect Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex and rifampicin resistance within 2 hours
options.B: It can differentiate between M. tuberculosis and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM)
options.C: It requires a biosafety level 3 laboratory for processing
options.D: It has low sensitivity in smear-negative, culture-positive samples

questions.explanation: within 2 hours hours Explanation: The GeneXpert MTB/RIF assay is a rapid, cartridge-based, automated nucleic acid amplification test that can detect both M. tuberculosis complex and rifampicin resistance in approximately 2 hours making it particularly valuable in high-burden, resource-limited settings. The GeneXpert MTB/RIF assay offers several advantages: Rapid results: Provides results in about 2 hours Simultaneous detection of M. tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance High specificity: >99% specific for M. tuberculosis complex Minimal biosafety requirements: Can be used outside of reference laboratories Automated interpretation: Reduces operator-dependent errors It can differentiate between M. tuberculosis and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) (Option B): While the GeneXpert MTB/RIF assay is highly specific for the M. tuberculosis complex, it cannot differentiate between M. tuberculosis and other members of the complex, nor can it identify NTM. This option is incorrect. It requires a biosafety level 3 laboratory for processing (Option C): One of the advantages of the GeneXpert system is that it allows for safe handling of specimens and can be used in lower biosafety level settings due to its closed-cartridge system. This option is incorrect. It has low sensitivity in smear-negative, culture-positive samples (Option D): While the sensitivity of GeneXpert is higher in smear-positive samples, it still maintains good sensitivity in smear-negative, culture-positive samples (60-80%), outperforming smear microscopy. This option is incorrect. Reference: Bailey & Scott's Diagnostic Microbiology, 14th Edition, Page 722-723 Murray's Medical Microbiology, 9th Edition, Page 241-242 Textbook of Microbiology, Ananthanarayan & Paniker, 10th Edition, Page 354-355

questions.question: A 28-year-old healthcare worker is being screened for latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI) as part of an occupational health program. Which of the following tests is considered the most specific for diagnosing LTBI in a person who has received BCG vaccination?
questions.explanation: is an Interferon-Gamma Release Assay (IGRA) that uses M. tuberculosis-specific antigens ESAT-6, CFP-10, and TB7.7 not present in BCG or most non-tuberculous mycobacteria, making it more specific for LTBI diagnosis in BCG-vaccinated individuals. Latent TB can be diagnosed by two tests: Tuberculin test /Mantoux test Interferon-Gamma Release Assay (IGRA) Tuberculin test /Mantoux test Antigen: Purified protein derivative (PPD) Procedure: 0.1 ml of PPD containing 5 TU (tuberculosis unit) is injected intradermally Examined after 48-72 hours Interpretation: Width of induration (measurement done perpendicular to the long axis of the forearm) Inference ≥ 10mm Positive 6-9mm Equivocal ≤ 5mm Negative Equivocal is considered positive in: HIV / Immunosupressed Known close contact H/o Prior TB Note: Erythema is not taken into consideration for the interpretation of results. Lower specificity in BCG-vaccinated individuals due to cross-reactivity with antigens present in the BCG vaccine and can yield false-positive results (Option A ruled out) Interferon-Gamma Release Assay (IGRA) Principle: T-lymphocytes release interferon-gamma when exposed to M. tuberculosis antigens. IGRAs like QuantiFERON-TB Gold In-Tube offer several advantages for LTBI diagnosis: Higher specificity in BCG-vaccinated individuals (negative in BCG-vaccinated individuals) No cross-reactivity with most non-tuberculous mycobacteria Requires only a single patient visit Results are available within 24-48 hours No boosting effect with repeated testing Disadvantage: Cannot differentiate between an active and inactive infection BacT / ALERT (Option C): It is an automated blood culture system designed to detect M. tuberculosis in clinical samples containing viable bacteria. It is not used for detecting latent tuberculosis. This option is incorrect. Chest X-ray (Option D) : It is not a specific test for LTBI. It may show changes suggestive of past TB exposure or active TB, but cannot definitively diagnose LTBI in BCG vaccinated person. This option is incorrect.

questions.question: A 35-year-old is being screened for latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI). Which of the following statements about Interferon-Gamma Release Assays (IGRAs) is correct? antigens

options.A: IGRAs use PPD as the stimulating antigen
options.B: IGRAs can differentiate between LTBI and active TB
options.C: IGRAs measure interferon-gamma released by T cells in response to specific M. tuberculosis
options.D: IGRAs can detect MPT64 antigen in patient samples

questions.explanation: tuberculosis antigens tuberculosis antigens Explanation: IGRAs measure interferon-gamma released by T cells in response to specific M. tuberculosis antigens, providing a measure of the cell-mediated immune response to TB infection. Interferon-Gamma Release Assay (IGRA) Principle: T-lymphocytes release interferon-gamma when exposed to M. tuberculosis antigens. IGRAs like QuantiFERON-TB Gold In-Tube offer several advantages for LTBI diagnosis: Higher specificity in BCG-vaccinated individuals (negative in BCG-vaccinated individuals) No cross-reactivity with most non-tuberculous mycobacteria Requires only a single patient visit Results are available within 24-48 hours No boosting effect with repeated testing Disadvantage: Cannot differentiate between an active and inactive infection LAM assay: Lipoarabinomannan (LAM) is a cell wall component of M. tuberculosis It can be detected in urine especially It can be useful in diagnosing active TB in HIV-positive patients with low CD4 counts MPT 64 patch test: (Option D ruled out) Antigen: Patch containing purified MPT64 protein Helps differentiate Mycobacterium.Tb from Atypical Mycobaterium Procedure: The patch is placed on the ventral surface of the forearm The skin reaction is read after 4 days Inference: Positive reaction: Erythema, induration or small red vesicles at the patch site IGRAs use PPD as the stimulating antigen (Option A): IGRAs do not use PPD (Purified Protein Derivative) as the stimulating antigen. Instead, they use M. tuberculosis-specific antigens like ESAT-6 and CFP-10. This option is incorrect. IGRAs can differentiate between LTBI and active TB (Option B): While IGRAs are excellent for detecting M. tuberculosis infection, they cannot distinguish between latent infection and active disease. This option is incorrect. Reference: Textbook of Microbiology, Ananthanarayan & Paniker, 10th Edition, Page 359-360 Bailey & Scott's Diagnostic Microbiology, 14th Edition, Page 730-731 Murray's Medical Microbiology, 9th Edition, Page 248-249 https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5947422/

questions.question: A newborn child in a high TB-burden country is being considered for BCG vaccination. Which of the following statements about the BCG vaccine is correct?

options.A: It provides 100% protection against all forms of tuberculosis
options.B: It is a live attenuated vaccine derived from Mycobacterium bovis
options.C: It is contraindicated in HIV-positive infants regardless of their immune status
options.D: It is most effective in preventing tuberculous meningitis in adults

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) It is a live attenuated vaccine derived from Mycobacterium bovis Explanation: BCG vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine derived from Mycobacterium bovis . It was first developed by Calmette and Guérin in 1921 through serial passages of a virulent M. bovis strain. BCG Strains: Different BCG strains are used worldwide, which may contribute to variations in vaccine efficacy. Route of Administration: Intradermally, usually in the left deltoid region Correct technique is crucial for optimal immune response and minimizing adverse effects Duration of Protection: It is not well-defined and may wane over time. It provides 100% protection against all forms of tuberculosis (Option A): The BCG vaccine does not provide complete protection against all forms of tuberculosis. Its efficacy varies widely (0-80%) depending on the form of TB and geographical location. It is most effective against severe forms of childhood TB, such as miliary TB and tuberculous meningitis. This option is incorrect. It is contraindicated in HIV-positive infants regardless of their immune status (Option C): While caution is needed, BCG is not universally contraindicated in all HIV-positive infants. The decision depends on the infant's immune status and local TB prevalence. It is contraindicated in symptomatic HIV infection but may be given to asymptomatic HIV-positive infants in high TB-burden settings. This option is incorrect. It is most effective in preventing tuberculous meningitis in adults (Option D): While BCG can provide some protection against tuberculous meningitis, it is most effective in preventing severe forms of TB in children, not adults. This option is incorrect. Reference: Bailey & Scott's Diagnostic Microbiology, 14th Edition, Page 735-736 Murray's Medical Microbiology, 9th Edition, Page 254-255

questions.question: A 30-year-old man presents with a non-healing ulcer on his left leg and hand. He gives a history of frequently swimming in a local pool. The ulcer grew in size gradually and developed into a chronic, painless granuloma as shown in the image. Which organism is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.explanation: with "swimming pool granuloma," resulting from exposure to contaminated water. The chronic, painless ulcer described depicts the case of an M. marinum infection. Non-tuberculous Mycobacteria (NTM) Definition: NTM are diverse mycobacteria found in soil, water, and animals, primarily affecting those with weakened immune systems Transmission: Not spread person-to-person; typically contracted from contaminated water or soil Runyon Classification of NTM Group Characteristics Examples Group I: Photochromogens Produce pigment in light; slow growth. M. kansasii (lung disease), (Option A ruled out) M. marinum ("swimming pool granuloma"). (Option B) Group II: Scotochromogens Produce pigment regardless of light; varied growth rates. M. scrofulaceum (swollen lymph nodes), M. gordonae (water contamination). Group III: Non-photochromogens No pigment production; diverse characteristics. M. avium complex (lung infections), (Option C ruled out) M. ulcerans (Buruli ulcers). Group IV: Rapid Growers Grow quickly; early colony formation. M. fortuitum (skin abscesses), (Option D ruled out) M. chelonae (injection site infections). Diagnosing Non-tuberculous Mycobacteria (NTM) Infections Microscopy: Acid-fast staining was used initially but was not conclusive for NTM diagnosis (shared with M. tuberculosis). Culture: Essential for definitive identification. Various growth rates help classify NTM species: NTM Group Growth Characteristics Rapid Growers Form colonies within days (e.g., M.fortuitum). Slow Growers May take weeks to form colonies (e.g., M.kansasii). Treatment : Specific to species and drug susceptibility. Includes prolonged multi-drug therapy. Surgery may be necessary for localized cases.

questions.question: A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with chronic cough, weight loss, and night sweats. Sputum culture grows colonies within two weeks, producing no pigment regardless of light exposure. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation: non-photochromogen. It does not produce pigment regardless of light exposure. It is known for causing lung infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. It is a slow grower, forming colonies within a few weeks. Group Characteristics Examples Group I: Photochromogens Produce pigment in light; slow growth. M. kansasii (lung disease), (Option A ruled out) M. marinum ("swimming pool granuloma"). (Option D ruled out) Group II: Scotochromogens Produce pigment regardless of light; varied growth rates. M. scrofulaceum (swollen lymph nodes), M. gordonae (water contamination). Group III: Non-photochromogens No pigment production; diverse characteristics. M. avium complex (lung infections), (Option C) M. ulcerans (Buruli ulcers). Group IV: Rapid Growers Grow quickly; early colony formation. M. fortuitum (skin abscesses), (Option B ruled out) M. chelonae (injection site infections). Reference: Textbook of Microbiology, Ananthanarayan & Paniker, 10th Edition, Page 366 to 369.

questions.question: Which type of leprosy is most likely affecting a patient who presents with localized, well-defined skin lesions and minimal bacterial presence?
questions.explanation: resistance, limited, well-defined skin lesions, and minimal bacterial presence. Transmission of Mycobacterium leprae Source of Infection: Leprosy is solely a human disease. Infected individuals are the only source. Transmission Route: The precise route is unclear. Significant shedding of bacilli through nasal secretions. Possible transmission through the respiratory tract or skin . Classification of Leprosy Madrid Classification: Type Characteristics Lepromatous Leprosy Low host resistance, abundant bacilli in lesions, widespread lesions, higher transmission likelihood (Option B ruled out). Tuberculoid Leprosy High resistance, limited well-defined skin lesions, minimal bacilli in the lesions (Option A). Dimorphous (Borderline) Characteristics of both lepromatous and tuberculoid forms, potential to shift between the two (Option C ruled out). Indeterminate Leprosy Early, unstable stage, may resolve spontaneously or progress to other forms (Option D ruled out). Ridley-Jopling Classification: Type Characteristics Tuberculoid (TT) High resistance, localized lesions Borderline Tuberculoid (BT) Intermediate between TT and BB, some features of both Borderline (BB) Intermediate, with features of both tuberculoid and lepromatous forms Borderline Lepromatous (BL) Intermediate between BB and LL, some features of both Lepromatous (LL) Low resistance, disseminated disease Category Lepromatous Leprosy (LL) Tuberculoid Leprosy (TT) Bacillary Load Multi-bacillary Pauci-bacillary Bacteriological Index Higher load (4-6+) Lower load (0-1+) Skin Lesions Leonine facies, Alopecia Few lesions Nerve Lesions Late Early Cell-mediated Immunity Low Normal Lepromin Test Negative Positive CD4/CD8 Ratio 1:2 2:1 Humoral Immunity Increased Normal Macrophages Foamy type Epithelioid type Giant Cells Negative Present This system provides a spectrum from TT (high resistance, localized lesions) to LL (low resistance, disseminated disease), characterizing the disease's progression. Classification Based on Bacterial Load: Classification Characteristics Associated Type Clinical Features Multibacillary Leprosy High bacterial load, clusters of bacilli ("globi") in lesions Lepromatous leprosy Low host resistance, widespread lesions, higher transmission risk Paucibacillary Leprosy Minimal bacterial presence Tuberculoid leprosy High host resistance, limited skin lesions Reference: Brock Biology of Microorganisms 15th Edition, Page 895, Textbook of Microbiology, Ananthanarayan & Paniker, 10th Edition, Page 372. 373.

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents with 5 hypoesthetic skin lesions on his arms, legs, along with palpable thickening of the ulnar nerve. There are no visible nodules. Skin smears reveal a low bacterial index. Which treatment regimen is most appropriate for this patient?

options.A: Rifampicin and dapsone daily for 6 months
options.B: Rifampicin monthly, daily dapsone, and daily clofazimine for 6 months
options.C: Rifampicin monthly and daily dapsone for 6 months
options.D: Rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine for 12 months

questions.explanation: patient's presentation with 5 hypoesthetic skin lesions and 1 thickened nerve without nodules is consistent with a paucibacillary form of leprosy. For paucibacillary leprosy , the WHO recommends the following regimen: Rifampicin : once a month Dapsone : daily Clofazimine : daily Diagnosis of Mycobacterium leprae Infection (Leprosy): Clinical Classification: Classified into multibacillary (MB) and paucibacillary (PB) forms based on bacterial load. Diagnostic Methods: Microscopy: Mainstay for detecting acid-fast bacilli (AFB) in nasal and skin smears by Ziehl-Neelsen staining. Nasal smears target shed bacilli; skin smears from lesion edges. Slit-skin smear enhances bacillus detection from small cuts. Grading Systems: Quantify bacilli to determine bacterial index (BI) Histopathology: Nodule or thickened nerve biopsy Culture: Mouse footpad or armadillo inoculation. Serological Tests and Molecular Methods. Treatment of Mycobacterium leprae Infection (Leprosy): Age group Drug Duration Adult Rifampicin - 600mg/month + Clofazimine - 300mg once a month & 50mg daily + Dapsone - 100mg daily Multibacillary - 12 months Paucibacillary - 6 months Children (10-14 years) Rifampicin - 450mg/month + Clofazimine - 150mg once a month & 50mg on alternate days + Dapsone - 50mg daily Multibacillary - 12 months Paucibacillary - 6 months Follow-Up Paucibacillary: 4 years Multibacillary: 8 years Research Immunotherapeutic vaccines (Mycobacterium W), alongside MDT, are being explored. Reference: Textbook of Microbiology, Ananthanarayan & Paniker, 10th Edition, Page 375. 376.

questions.question: A patient with chronic leprosy develops sudden onset of red, swollen, and tender lesions on existing skin patches. Which of the following reactions is most likely occurring in this patient?
questions.explanation: presentation of sudden onset red, swollen, and tender lesions in a patient with chronic leprosy is characteristic of Type 2 Reaction, also known as Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL) . ENL is an inflammatory response triggered by antigens released from dead M. leprae cells, leading to neutrophil infiltration and the formation of tender subcutaneous nodules. This reaction typically occurs in lepromatous and borderline lepromatous cases, often a few months into chemotherapy. Character Lepra Reaction Type I Lepra Reaction Type II Hypersensitivity Type IV (Delayed Hypersensitivity) Type III (Immune Complex-Mediated) Seen with Borderline leprosy (BL), Lepromatous leprosy (LL) Lepromatous variety (LL) Manifests as Inflammation of previous lesions, new skin lesions, and neuritis Crops of painful erythematous papules which become nodular, called ENL (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum) Progresses as If it occurs before treatment, progresses towards LL (down-grading reaction) If it occurs after treatment, it progresses towards TT (reversal reaction) Usually occurs following the start of chemotherapy T-helper Response TH1 predominates, leading to increased IFN- γ and IL-2 TH2 predominates, leading to increased IL-6 and IL-8. TNF- α plays a central role Other organs affected Usually not affected Eyes, testes, and kidneys are affected Treatment Glucocorticoid Glucocorticoid, thalidomide, clofazimine, and antipyretics Lepromatous Transformation (Option C): It doesn’t refer to a sudden reaction but rather to a shift toward the lepromatous end of the leprosy spectrum. It is characterized by a gradual increase in bacterial load and spread of lesions, rather than the acute onset of tender lesions. This option is incorrect. Tuberculoid Transformation (Option D): It doesn’t indicate an acute reaction. It refers to a shift toward the tuberculoid form, usually indicating an improved immune response. However, such transformation does not cause acute inflammation or red, tender lesions as seen in the patient. This option is incorrect. Reference: Textbook of Microbiology, Ananthanarayan & Paniker, 10th Edition, Page 374.
